Alamo Square.name: Alamo Square
reviews:
The park sits up high on a hill providing some great views of the city. Park was filled with people and families out for walks, playing on the playground, sitting on benches, etc., very peaceful. Park is a bit hilly. The painted lady homes are just across the street and those were beautiful to see as well.
Show less

Nice to see the painted ladies of San Francisco. The house from full house is found in this area, as well. The park is great. Many locals walking their dogs and families playing with their kids. We felt safe in this area as we walked all around.
Show less
We took our Full(er) House fan for the obvious reasons, but we were all pleasantly surprised by the nice children's playground and lovely park

This park has a nice view of the beautiful painted ladies. Alamo Square always makes me think of full house. This was quite a walk from Union Square but I think it was worth it. I'm a full house nerd and this was on my bucket list.
Show less

It's really nothing more than a cute little park with nice views of the city. While the painted ladies are pretty, they're nothing spectacular, and Alamo Square in and of itself wasn't worth more than a half hours visit, if that.
It's just a park with a nice view

Sure it has a view of some famous houses and a pretty nice view of the skyline but it is just a small park. If you go there not thinking it will be anything other than maybe a couple minutes to take a picture then you won't be disappointed.

We took a Lyft there and then walked to a nearby restaurant for lunch and on to Golden Gate park. If you plan out your time on that side if the city you'll have some nice walks and can enjoy the quiet neighborhoods and parks.
Show less
A beautiful park on a hill in the city

If you want a peaceful break inside the city, go here. This is a lovely green patch of SF with lovely old homes around and great views. You may also enjoy the natives walking their pups. It was easy to get to on the MUNI (bus) system from BART.
Show less
Relaxt small City park with great views

Predominantly used by locals to walk their dogs this park lies on a plateau providing great vistas on down town SAN fran. It has a relaxed mellow vibe to it. Nice for a morning stroll with Some espesso to go
you can park long the side of the road but be careful for street sweeper times posted. a nice clean park. pretty view!

went there for the view of the painted ladies, but honestly found those to be a bit overrated. The park was a great place for a nice city view and the view of the other side of the city was even more impressive. We were there at sunset so it was really beautiful
It's honestly not a super special place and I'm not even sure why it's on the tourist list, but it's a beautiful park area to hang around if that's what you're looking for
Show less
It is a good place to see the famous painted ladies and it's best if you have a car to drive to this place, because you will not have what to do more at this place.

Vernacular New World domestic architecture...reminded me, on a much larger scale of course, of hillside houses in Wellington and in the port of Lytellton.. They're lovely, gracious houses arranged around a square full of huge pine trees. This is surprising and at odds with the tamed comfortable nature of the houses. I think I expected a flower gardeny sort of park in that context, really. The views of the SF downtown skyline are fun. And the interesting and pretty houses continue in the surrounding streets and right into Haight Ashbury, which is only a short walk away, meaning that if you have time, this is a fun all day expedition. The square is easily accessed by trolley or bus from the terminus at the junction of Market and Powell and the line runs all the way past Golden Gate Park and down to Ocean Beach. So you can hit lots of high spots by branching out from here.
Show less
Beautiful park and view of skyline and painted ladies
Must visit if you are in San Fran! Very accessible and beautifully maintained park. If not cold, great for picnic too. Perfect view of skyline and painted ladies - great for photos.
Beautiful houses with nice backdrop of the San Francisco skyline. It is a tourist trap so be prepared to wait for a good picture.

The Painted Ladies next to Alamo Square are cute and worth a few photos, but I'm not quite sure why they're so popular.

They're nice old houses situated in a row which obviously have had plenty of money spent on their upkeep and relatively fresh paint jobs...that is all.
Show less
The painted lady Homes are visible from the park The park is quite large The Victorian homes facing the park are beautifully and individually painted
Fun to see the painted ladies, watched them in the credits of full house for years, nice to see them in person

Been renting from Alamo for years in the USA ( from Uk)
Rented from here in August - the car was booked from 9am but we had to wait 2 hours as the car wasn’t there. They tried to fob us off with an “upgrade” instead of a caravan with a broken seat. We waited for this car to arrive and it had a massive dent and scratch down the side. The manager said it’s fine don’t worry I will make a note on the paperwork. I took a video of the damage and of him signing the paperwork. Today 3 months after returning the car I receive an email from the damage department asking me to complete the claim form for the damage !
It’s been 3 months ! I imagine they deliberately wait that long hoping people have no proof left or can’t remember. They provided poor service and are now trying to charge me for their damaged car ! So unfair .
Don’t trust them .
Show less

We took our children to the Alamo on vacation. We spent hour's touring ang looking at all of the sites. My teenage boy's were fascinated! This is the place you want to take your kid's if you're in texas!!!

Alamo square (and the painted ladies) is something you definitely don't get to see everyday, so I would highly recommend visiting (especially if you are not from the US).
I was lucky enough to visit when there was no fog and it was not raining so there were many people in Alamo square with their dogs or having picnics and just relaxing.
Worth a visit!
Show less

This park covers an entire block and the painted ladies are just one end of it. Lots of space here with a tennis court, Children's playground and a free roaming Dog area. So take time to view all of it. 1973
A must to see painted ladies & victorian houses

One must visit this square to see Painted Ladies or Colorful Victorian houses which are pretty old, as old as as 100 to 150 years but well maintained & very expensive. Its a very Rich Neighbourhood of hardly 2000 homes.
Nice park with a great view of the city and the painted ladies. We had no issue with parking and it was not overly crowded.
Beautiful views and perfect for photos!

Alamo Square is very beautiful the park itself! I have been wanting to come here since watching Full House which I grew up with. I was so excited to see the Painted Ladies and I really felt like singing the Full House theme song. This is a must visit spot you will not regret it!
Show less
It's a good place to take a rest. You have a beautiful view on the painted ladies and the skyline of San Francisco. A must see place.

A small and cozy square/park in front of the painted ladies. A square on a hill with a lovely view of SF, not quite high enough to view all of the city but you get a lovely glimpse of it.

The park wasn't too crowded on this Wednesday but I hear on the weekends it is really busy.
Show less
Great view of the San Francisco Skyline

We went here for the beautiful view of the San Francisco Skyline. The houses next to the park is also a pleasant view.

We went here first thing in the morning and the fog totally ruined our view. We grabbed some coffee and waited it out though. It was kind of amazing to see how the city eventually cleared through the fog.
Show less
Most photgraphed spot in San Francisco

Park is worth stopping by. Great place for dog watching esp after work and on weekends, Several nice bed and breakfast's and restaurants in the neighborhood Chateau Tivoli. Alamo Square Fish House, Located about as central as possible for lodging yet quite at night
The famouse painted ladies of San Francisco

Newly remodel park with lovely views of the city and the often photograph "Painted Ladies Of San Francisco" It can be a bit crowed on sunny days, come and check them out bring a picnic basket and watch families and dogs play in the park. And soak up the views.... You will leave your heart in San Francisco after you leave this park.....
Show less
came here at night for a short period just to see the painted ladies (full house intro) not the actual house . the city is in the backdrop behind the houses and looks amazing
Dramatic views of San Francisco skyline from Alamo Square

Located in the Hayes Valley district of San Francisci, Alamo Square is a large four block park with dramatic views because of its steep elevation. Bordered by Fulton, Steiner, Hayes and Scott streets, this urban green space has open grass where locals exercise their dogs, a public tennis court, and restroom facilities but most importantly has some of the best panoramic views of the San Francisco city skyline, City Hall and the painted ladies, the magnificently restored Victorian Era homes along Steiner Street.
The square is often crowded with tourists and Finding parking can be a major challenge, especially if parallel parking on a steep hill is not familiar to you.
Show less

If you want the best view of downtown San Francisco go to Alamo Square. You also get to see the famous painted ladies which is an added bonus. The Park is great for a rest (sleep!!) if you are having a busy day sightseeing and you can easily catch a trolley bus back to downtown from alongside the square
Show less

Get a trolley bus, jump onto a muni bus and you get to Alamo square with its beautiful Victorian ladies- houses painted in lovely colours surrounding a beautiful park. Views across the city to the bay are stupendous and the experience of being able to navigate round the city is great. Everyone wants to help you get where you want to go but with a map you can get anywhere
Show less

We went to Alamo Square to see tge famous Painted Ladies. However there were so many beautiful old homes in the area it made me wonder why the Painted Ladies became so famous. In truth it must be the background that makes those particular homes so photographed.
Show less
Take a walk back in time.

If you want to see what San Francisco used to look like, head to Alamo Square. This small-ish park in San Francisco provides great views but more importantly allows you to see some great historical architecture.

The beautiful ‘Painted Ladies’ give you an insight into how the Victorians lived and displayed their wealth to their neighbours. Still, generally, very well preserved, this quick break from the busy city allows you to pause and take a quick trip back in time.
Show less

The houses are in a nice area with a grass park in front of them.
They are a bit out of the way from the usual visitor areas.
There are many other houses in San Francisco that are as good as these but this seems to be the only place where there are 5 together.
If you like architecture of this period you have to walk around the residential areas of San Francisco.
You will need a spare memory card for your camera as there are so many houses of this type between the other buildings .
Show less
Lovely Park, Great for Picnic and Views!

So glad the park was open this year when we visited. We stopped by Alamo Square last October and were so disappointed, but all that disappointment was erased this time around. What a beautiful hilltop park which takes up the enter block. The views from the top of the city behind the painted ladies is iconic and a must see. The homes all around the square are beautiful. Lots of shade and open space great for picnics, strolling around the park or playing with your dog. There was even a coffee shop truck parked in the park which was a gem. Parking around the square can be tough during peaks but we didn't have any trouble on a Friday around lunch (it was still full of locals and tourists).
Show less

This has to be one of the most iconic views of San Francisco, identifying the city at once through many movies and TV shows. They must be the most photographed houses on earth! But, the park itself is an oasis of green and one of many around San Francisco, which relieve the built up areas. Go see the ladies at least once in your lifetime!
Show less
If you remember the opening of Full House, then this is where that row of homes are located. There is a great park across the street and frankly takes up the whole square block in Alamo Square.
Just like the TV shows opening credits, just have to walk to the top of the park and get the right angle. Really nice view of the city,
We visited the square to see the famous "painted ladies" and they are beautiful. One can stroll around the square and enjoy the walk.
Beautiful Park! Great view of Full House Street!
This is a beautiful part to have a picnic or just walk around. Great place to take a picture in front of the famous row of houses that is in the intro to the original Full House Show.

Stop in to see the famous painted ladies, but then walk down to Divisadero and grab some food for a picnic. On a nice day the park is sunny and warm and perfect for a picnic. There's a good playground and an area for dogs too.
Show less
Reputed to be the most photographed homes in San Francisco
You've probably seen the "painted ladies" aka Victorian homes in magazines in commercials... Pretty impressive! Fun to see.
If you are a Full House fan this is a fun quick stop. These are the houses that were in the intro to the show not the house where the family "lived" in the show. Was still a fun stop for quick pics.

This is where you will see the postcard view of the line of Victorian houses right up close. Plus it's a very pleasant park. Good views of SF downtown. Surrounded by unique and spectacular architecture. On the tourist route.

Just sit at this vantage point to see the Painted Ladies. Watch the sun set behind them and its beautiful. Everyone is so chilled hanging out and having picnics. Another side to the beautiful and scenic San Francisco.
Everyone goes to Alamo Square to see the famous Painted Ladies. That's where the crowds come from. Not a great place to have a picnic or relax. FYI, these aren't the houses from the show Full House.

I really loved the painted ladies with the San Fran landscape in the background. We sat in the park and admired the view. Careful if you park here, we saw a lot of broken glass on the floor from car break ins.

I did see some of the Victorian's in the Haight Ashbury area which I thought were incredible examples of the enchanted Painted Ladies, but my curiosity was now peaked to see the famous view of the iconic Victorians at the park.
The SF Ladies are a bit different from Cape May, NJ's structures being that a lot of them are situated on a hill & are extremely close together, but both cities can boast about their captivating colorful charm.
The Alamo Park setting photographed so well. An added bonus is the view of the city in the background. I will remember Alamo Square as being a quaint city park where the public can leisurely spend some time not only viewing the brilliance of these man made historic homes, but also mother natures gift of greenery.
Show less
Beautiful Victorian homes. The painted ladies are must see, educational and Informative. Definitely a family adventure
Loved the painted ladies Victorian houses beautiful view and skyline San Francisco such a beautiful City lots to see
Had to go here for the op photo and the historic relevance of this San Fran landmark. My wife and I had been in SF before but not here. Nice square with beautiful houses. Recommend it highly.

We had cheese and biscuits and good drinks when we visit the park and have a look at this famous houses. With a MUNI-bus pass it`s Easy to get here. On top of the hill it`s a good look over a part of San Francisco.

Was in downtown SF for business and had a free afternoon to explore. Took the 5 bus from Union Square so didnt have to worry about parking. Popular place to see the Painted Ladies and the SF skyline. It's a small park, just recently renovated. Walk around the square to get a good shot of the houses and the skyline.
Show less
Great place to spend a lazy day

Alamo square has some great view points of the city, but most famously the painted ladies, a group of 7 victorian style houses that make for a great photo opportunity, and one of the most visited places in San Francisco. The parking situation around alamo square is all parallel street parking, but I had no issues finding a spot to park. There's a few great walking paths and a playground for kids to play on, along with bathroom facilities. There is also a pretty awesome view of Coit Tower. Definitely recommend stopping by.
Show less
If you like details, this is the right place to visit. These houses are full of details in their architecture. Sitting at the park feels good, or just laying on the lawn. Nice friend to walk around.
The view from the park above the Painted Ladies is simply gorgeous. The painted ladies are so pretty too.
What you see on TV and Movies

If you remember the opening credits of Full House you will recognize this area. The Square is just that. A large Square Grassy area. There are some great views of San Francisco, and you can see the famous houses on the hill. This is not where the Full House is, but you can find it in town. We stopped briefly to take in the view, but you might be fine just driving by the square and on. It would be a nice place for a picnic in nice weather.
Show less
Alamo Square--Just a Park with Great Views

San Fransisco is a beautiful city. Really an amazingly beautiful city. With breathtaking views at nearly every turn. It is also a city with smallish parks dotting its landscape. And, many of these parks offer amazing and wonderful scenic views.

Alamo Square is one of these wonderful urban oasis with great views. And, the famous Painted Ladies houses are across the street from the park.

In San Fransisco, the parks are packed with people (on nice weather days). Families with kids on blankets. Twenty-somethings hanging out because the weather is great. And, at Alamo Square, there is a large section for people with dogs.

Great view. Cool to see the Painted Ladies. I'm not sure it would be a destination site. We hit four parks on our personal walking tour and they were all great.
Show less
To be very honest the houses in san Francisco are so pretty i dont think the painted ladies are nothing special. In alamo square you have beautiful views of the city

My granddaughter had begged to see the Painted Laddies from TV;s Full House. She was not disappointed. We walked around seeing so many more painted ladies similar to the row. Actually it was very interesting to see how many variations there were and the unique architecture. We took the 21 bus from Market Street and back. The park has restrooms if needed. Great views of the city from the top of the hill..
Show less
good view of the city, nice architecture around the square

First - the children's playground - it is great but DIRTY! I've never encountered my children (5 years and toddler) getting so filthy after a trip here. Plan on kids having a bath afterwards. It also has a lot of sand - so we take some little accessories to have fun with it (shovels, buckets etc). The view of the city whilst pushing my little one on the swing is awesome. I love the houses in this city, and yes, the Painted Ladies are lovely to look at. I feel awful for the owners having tourists gawk at their homes all day long. I was surprised by the number of people there for these houses (and the view). There is a public toilet near the playground - I've never used it but it tends to have a queue of people the times I've been there.
Show less
Alamo square is a very nice place to visit. You can see The Painted Ladies and also take some great photos of San Francisco. The view is breathtaking!!!

If visiting San Francisco, one must visit the beautiful painted ladies near the Alamo Square. They are Victorian style homes painted with artistry. Many believe that they were used for the outdoor scene of the television series Full House.

Beautiful park with wonderful architecture completely surrounding it! Get there early on a Sunday and you won't have a problem finding a spot to park! And don't forget to check out the old haunted mansion looking house on one of the close by corners!
Amazing, but careful about parking around-freuqnet car breakins

I spend some time there before going to the airport. Amazing view on a par at the top of SF. However, bad surprise on the way back. My car rental had a window smashed and a backpack with a laptop taken. Apparently they happen frequently every day. So, watch out. Do not park around and if you do do not leave anything in the car. They would need some video canera around, would love to get these rats.
Show less

We walked through the park to the other side to see the Victorian Houses. Okay, saw them, took a few pictures and that's it, you wont even spend 15 minutes here. We walked through the park to get to the side of the houses, not too thrilled to see all the dogs from the dog park running freely around, even on the walking path. I get it, its a dog park but where they are suppose to be not where people are relaxing, sitting and walking about.
Don't think this is a must on anyone's list. Its just pretty houses at the end of the day.
Show less

Warning - car break-ins in this area are very common. We parked our car and walked the park for 15 minutes to see the Painted Ladies (row of houses). When we came back, our car and another car had windows smashed on. Our car only had things like coloring books stolen but the car was a rental and it took time to go back to the airport for an exchange, not to mention the cost of repairing a broken window. A woman walking by said that this happens every day. We borrowed a broom from a gentleman who lives across the street and he said that car break-ins are very common here. My advice if you're visiting from out of town: drive by the houses, don't stop at the park. Or take an Uber.
Show less
I love the view. Reminds me of full house and now fuller house. What a great view. A good background for a scenic shot.
Another small park where you can relax and have a nice view of San Francisco. You can easily relax on the meadow, take a picnic or sunbath.
places to see in San Francisco
One-of-a-kind attraction! Only in San Francisco! Nostalgic and historic remembrance of old houses in view. The park is newly renovated and worth the trip to visit. A "must" see!
We had to see this. Painted Ladies. The houses were something to see and this is where Full HOuse was filmed. They had just re-opened the park across the street. Beautiful
Awesome park to relax and take pics of the painted ladies. Has a nice area for the kids to place in the swings and slides. And great for pics
Go there once in your life
The houses are pretty but they don't look like this photo. Many have been painted different colors and it is rarely sunny. Still a good park to walk around.
This area is well kept and seems to be popular with a lot of tourist as many people had cameras while we checked out this area.
It is always fun to see a childhood memory in real life except the park across the street which would normally allow you to take good pics is under construction and parking is TOUGH

We went to see the "painted ladies" and it was definitely worth it. SF sky line from the top of the hill are breathtaking and the views of the "Painted ladies" worth the trip. The park is under construction but I do not regret going.
These house are grand, elegant and beautiful. The park was closed so we couldnt get a more elevated photo of the painted ladies but never the less they are a sight not to be missed.
Not what I expected and over rated.

We took a few buses before we got to Alamo square...that was fun with the kids. Considering they are big fans of Full House this is why we wanted to go. They were disappointed since the house doesn't look the same. Would i trek all over town to see this place...NO. The park across the street was also under construction which made it even more of an 'average' experience.
Show less

The area is under construction, but that will be ending soon our tour guide had told us. That said, this is a beautiful area with awesome views of the bay. However, bring your hiking shoes as that hill is brutal coming from the east up,...More

I have a tween daughter, so this was a must on our trip. The park is under construction, but is still quite nice. We did a hop on hop off tour and had to walk a few blocks from where they let you off. Great...More
The square across from the Painted Ladies

It was a bucket list experience to see the Painted Ladies while I was in San Francisco! What better way to appreciate the ladies than sitting on the beautiful grassy square right across the road on a perfect sunny day!

Alamo Square is famous for the Victorian style houses called Painted Ladies. We stumbled on this place while on a walking tour of SF. The houses have amazing architecture and during sunset, the place is really spectacular.
Such beautiful homes in this area. All the different colours and designs. Made for some good photography.

We walked from the city hall all the way to the painted ladies and the walk there was as nice as the ladies. There are so many gorgeous houses on the way there. If we go back to San Francisco we will defentely go there...More

Honestly, if you've seen a picture, that's pretty much it. Not much different from houses we saw all, over SF. My kids wanted to see it because of the opening credits of Full House (note: Full House House is in a different location). 10 minutes...More
I walk by here every May with Bay to Breakers
A nice park to visit and lots going on in the Hayes Valley area with restaurants, coffee shops and cafes.

Alamo Square was fenced up, with the exception of a corner. You could see the Painted Ladies, but with a chain link fence as foreground. Be careful not to leave anything in plain view inside cars: I saw a couple of break-ins, despite the crowded...More
Go and take your photos. It's obligatory. But seriously, this is a nice park in a formerly sketchy area, now very safe and prosperous. Pretty park, great views.
Great example of San Francisco architecture and fun to see if you watch the TV show Full House. These homes are in the open shot of the show.
Great city landmark with a park and good view. Parking is difficult so it is best to take the BART or public transportation.
Park close, but able to see the painted ladies

Park was close because of some remodeling and new grass on the gardens. Really nice place, but careful, we saw some glass on the sidewalks and I asked local people and they confirmed that during night, cars can get open or broke glasses to get whats inside of the cars.
View of the painted ladies are great...
Looks like an expensive neighborhood..
Show less

A great day out with lots of parking. Alamo Square is a lovely green park located across the road from the painted ladies. Go and enjoy a relaxing walk around the park or just sit back and admire the scenary of the beautifully painted ladies. Great for the whole family, park has a play ground for the kids.
Show less

San Francisco is know for the beautiful Victorian style homes, these on Alamo Square even more so known as the "Painted Ladies" these vibrant Victorians are located on Steiner St in the Haight Ashbury neighbourhood. The park was being renovated when we were there.
Not a must-see place in San Francisco due to the construction

Alamo Square may be a popular spot for tourists, but we didn't find it that interesting, especially with the construction going on as of February 2017. At this point you can't walk in the park or take any good photos with the green grass in the foreground and the colourful houses in the back. There are fences everywhere and even though many tourists visit this place it really is not a must-see unless you have plenty of time and want to cover the whole city. That said, this is a nice area and one can walk from here all the way to the University of San Francisco and from there enter the Golden Gate Park, located in the southwest of the city. You can also walk the other direction and discover lots of little cafe places and enjoy the peace and quiet. This area is very different from the eastern and northern shores of the city, bustling with tourists and locals. This is a quiet residential area where people walk their dogs and tourists come to take photos. I believe it might be better once the construction is finished and the weather gets warmer. Then people could actually hang out at the park and maybe even have a little picnic.
Show less
Square currently under reconstruction, but the photo point is still available
Square currently under reconstruction, but the photo point is still available. It is possible to park at the square. The view is indeed as we know it from movies...
The Painted Ladies - how many shows/movies have they appeared in?

Tourists everywhere and limited parking. . . park is being "rejuvenated" for the next couple of months so there is blue fencing in the way of your picture taking and the park is MUDDY! Go early in the day (but the "Ladies" will be in the shade) to avoid the insane crowds. Be aware of many car break in's in the area . . . they watch you get out of your car . . . have someone drive around the block and come back to pick you up instead. A must see if you have a family member who is a fan of "Full House"
Show less
The famous clips from Full House. Park was under construction but still able to see the famous view. I went in the afternoon and not as many people.
This is where you can see the painted ladies but get ready for tourists everyone and huge RVs trying to park. The architecture is beautiful so I did enjoy seeing them.

The Alamo Sq and its park from where the Seven Ladies are best seen is currently renovating. There's a small part accessible for taking pics, but no need to come if it's not on your way.
Such houses, even more beautiful can be seen in all of SF, specially around Haight-Ashbury.
Show less
Drove by on bus tour of San Francisco. Beautiful Victorian homes in pastel colours. Very nice neighbourhood and expensive. Visited in September 2016.
Quite far out To snap a photo of a row of houses. Ok it might mean more to some people. But for someone from the UK. Yep. Houses. Shall we got to the pub?
The most iconic view in San Francisco.

This is it! The most iconic view in San Francisco. The painted ladies of Alamo Square! The park itself has a great vista for one of the best views of the City By the Bay, but also has a dog run, playground and several tennis courts. The streets (on all 4 sides) are lined with the beauty of wonderful examples of Victorian archetecture.
Show less

I was surprised how many families and other visitors had the same idea that we had, to visit the Painted Ladies. They is featured on the American TV sitcom, "Full House." The park across the street, currently under construction, but still featuring benches to sit and reflect on the city, offer a nice view of the homes, and the city beyond.
Show less
The view toward downtown (Transamerica Bldg) is iconic

The park has construction fencing around it is not worth spending much time, but the view of the Painted Ladies and downtown is iconic. Worth a 10 minute stop on your driving tour of the neighborhoods.
Cmon folks-leave the people who live in these houses alone. There are better views elsewhere. They are.
There was construction on the park so it was a little crowded when we went on the weekend, so watch out for tourists (including you).
A dog friendly park, but more meaning than that for me

Alamo Square and Park on the western addition is probably mostly known as the best spot to view the ‘Painted Ladies’, but it offers a lot more. There are many residences in the neighborhood and at the center is this park. The park is a very popular doggie walk area, has a tennis court, benches, grassy area, trees, and restrooms facilities that on my visit were soon closing down for the summer and fall for severely needed upgrades and repairs.

This park also happens to be located at the top of the only hill during the course of the annual Bay to Breakers race. The musicians, performers and well-wishers along this tough section of the race was beyond a doubt always the most inspiring and motivating area for me during the entire race, which I will always appreciate and respect.
Show less

This is a great little spot that you can get to via the city tour bus. The actual square facing the famous houses is quite nice and may be worth packing a picnic and sitting in there for a while. It's not a big place so not much time is needed, but it's still quite nice and not over crowded
Show less
I always love the Painted Ladies
Some beautiful Victorian homes. These homes have been around for a long time, and still look amazing. I love visiting Alamo Square for a quiet afternoon when I'm in SF.

We remembered this from Full House and the initial impression was a little disappointing as they were re seeding the grassed area across the road. But the houses are amazing. the painted ladies are just a small example of just fabulous architecture of the time. Great to walk around and look.
Show less
Limited views for the time being

Alamo Square Park is currently being remodeled/relandscaped/whatever. The whole area is dirt and is fenced off. The bottom line is that you're not allowed even half way up the hill, which means that you're not going to get good pictures of the Painted Ladies with downtown in the background. It doesn't stop people from coming though. If you can manage to grab a bench, you can have a very pleasant and scenic sit-down for as long as you'd like.
Show less
Nice Victorian architecture, but there are other sections of town that are just as architecturally relevant

This landmark neighborhood and square is known for its beautiful Victorian architecture but it's important to know that there are many other neighborhoods in the city that have just as nice Victorian houses with amazing gingerbread and character. This is also the place where a scene from the first part of Tales of the City was filmed.

This is a great place to take pictures of the house from the TV show Full house. Even if you haven't seen it the houses are pretty

First of all, Alamo Square is under renovation, it is no longer a good place to view the skyline of San Francisco.

Secondly, with so many tourists daily to "view" the Painted Ladies, I pity the residents of the 6 households.

I witnessed how 3 Asian ladies taking turns to pose and take their individual and group portrait in front of the houses, at the middle of the road in order to take the "perfect" picture. There were even tourists who parked in front of the houses in order to take pictures. It is intrusive, dangerous and disrespectful. If you entire purpose is to take the shot and show off to people you have been there, buy a postcard and you could always Photoshop yourself on it...

If you want to appreciate the buildings in a more quiet atmosphere, pick any building along Golden Gate Avenue or walk along Haight Ashbury.

For Guide Books, pls take this "tourist attraction" out of your book.

It is a nice view from the park. I can see that it will be very nice when the renovation is complete. I wouldn't consider this a must see on a short trip to SF, however we are staying for a month and thought it was a nice stop.

Best Spot to Shot The Painted Ladies
This is the place to be to shot the Painted Ladies, because you can have a better angle for your pictures and put the SFO Bay just behind them all.
Few people take advantage of the Site of Seven Sisters in the middle of Town.

Take a lot of picures here. Do selfies in front of iconic Victorians. See the City from the top of the hill. Enter the Bishop's Inn opposite the Victorian homes to see wonderful decor, terrific architecture and an incredible stained glass skylight at the top of an elegant circular staircase. This is the Heart of San Francisco. If you can manage it take a room at an Inn on Alamo Square. You won't forget it or regret it. Drive up or taxi to Clement Street, the Other Suburban Chinatown. Tour the shops, see the Asian Foods and eat a great meal at prices far from the tourist traps. All of the shops and retaurants are West of Divisadero.
Get directions or use GPS to tour the Presidio on 49 Mile Drive. See the bridges and the Pacific Ocean. Drink it in. This is a city to leave your heart in.

Come for the Painted Ladies on Steiner Stay for drinks coffee or food

This is my hood and though it has changed. It offers so so so much. There is music at the Independent. I've seen Gregg Allman and a band called Yemen Blues that make you dance. I've eaten at Nopalito and I recommend the pork and cabbage salad.I've walked up to Flybar to sit with a friend in the window soaking up the sun and enjoyed their house piazza.I've had breakfast at the Grind on Haight and Scott and I've walked the panhandle to get to work. There's a record store, You can get your nails done or just walk along Divisadero. It's noisy,vibrant and alive.

The Home of "Full House" is Found Here and the Painted Ladies!

So, if you are or were a fan of the Olsen sisters and the series Full House, you will want to visit this site. The home featured in the show is1709 on Broderick Street. There is a pretty and typically sunny park in this square where dogs run about. May be a spot to rest and eat.

Make sure you walk around San Francisco when you visit, and get out of the touristy sites into the city.

Alamo Square is a good place to start a walk to see the real San Francisco. There are great shops on Divisadero (around Golden Gate) and Fillmore Streets (around Sacramento Street). It is much better to stay out here and away from Fisherman's Wharf, the Tenderloin or downtown, for instance, the Metro Hotel on Divisadero or the Stanyan Inn, or airbnb it. This area is not far from Baker Beach, the Presdio, Fort Point on the way across the Golden Gate Bridge, Golden Gate Park, the Castro, the Haight and the streets in between. It is a real mistake to stay only in the downtown and never stay in the Tenderloin, which for some reason, is where Euros often end up -- must be their travel sites send them that way. Also, recognize that summer is cold in SF, so plan part of your trip in Napa or the foothills or Sierras for some summer sun.

will be really nice once the renovations are complete
Any Full House fan must go. It looks just like on the show. But that is all there is to do there right now. Look and take a picture.

This is easy to go see with the public transportation in San Francisco. Beautiful photos of the painted ladies can be obtained especially on a beautiful sunny day. They tend to look more dull if it's overcast. Recommend for the photo op especially if you don't have much time to spend here.

Cute place. Unfortunately the park was under construction when we went (late June). But we were able to get pics of the "Full House" house. Super cute.

A gorgeous area!

If you're in SF, have a picnic and sit in Alamo Square across from the famous Painted Ladies. Those Victorian houses have become famous from all sorts of TV shows and Movies but especially Full House. Even if you aren't a fan of the show, these houses are postcard ready with a click of the camera. People watch in Alamo Square too. Watch Hipsters, hippie and people hanging out with their dogs and people hula-hooping it up. It's quite relaxing and fun.

Want to see the Painted Ladies....this is the place.

Alamo Square is the small park across the street from the Painted Ladies. Because this is fairly out of the way, we took a cab over and the driver suggested he stay to wait for us. Thank goodness he did! We snapped a few photos and were done. It was desolate on a Sunday morning so we would have been stuck without him waiting. If you're nostalgic for your childhood like me, the chance to snap some photos is worth a visit. You'll need 15 minutes tops and you'll be back on your way. Enjoy the views on your way to and from the area. You'll pass some amazing homes as you travel through the Pacific Heights.
